I think that you have heard all this 'from yourself, and not from me'; nor did I say this, which you erroneously attribute to me, but you yourself, and what you said was very true.
For indeed, my dear fellow, the design which you meditate of teaching what you do not know, and have not taken any pains to learn, is downright insanity.

275.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: But, Socrates, I think that the Athenians and the rest of the Hellenes do not often advise as to the more just or unjust; for they see no difficulty in them, and therefore they leave them, and consider which course of action will be most expedient; for there is a difference between justice and expediency.
Many persons have done great wrong and profited by their injustice; others have done rightly and come to no good.

276.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, but granting that the just and the expedient are ever so much opposed, you surely do not imagine that you know what is expedient for mankind, or why a thing is expedient?

277.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Why not, Socrates?—But I am not going to be asked again from whom I learned, or when I made the discovery.

278.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What a way you have!

When you make a mistake which might be refuted by a previous argument, you insist on having a new and different refutation; the old argument is a worn-our garment which you will no longer put on, but some one must produce another which is clean and new.
Now I shall disregard this move of yours, and shall ask over again,—Where did you learn and how do you know the nature of the expedient, and who is your teacher?

All this I comprehend in a single question, and now you will manifestly be in the old difficulty, and will not be able to show that you know the expedient, either because you learned or because you discovered it yourself.

But, as I perceive that you are dainty, and dislike the taste of a stale argument, I will enquire no further into your knowledge of what is expedient or what is not expedient for the Athenian people, and simply request you to say why you do not explain whether justice and expediency are the same or different?
And if you like you may examine me as I have examined you, or, if you would rather, you may carry on the discussion by yourself.

279.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: But I am not certain, Socrates, whether I shall be able to discuss the matter with you.

280.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then imagine, my dear fellow, that I am the demus and the ecclesia; for in the ecclesia, too, you will have to persuade men individually.

281.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

282.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is not the same person able to persuade one individual singly and many individuals of the things which he knows?
The grammarian, for example, can persuade one and he can persuade many about letters.

283.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

284.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And about number, will not the same person persuade one and persuade many?

285.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

286.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And this will be he who knows number, or the arithmetician?

287.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Quite true.

288.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And cannot you persuade one man about that of which you can persuade many?

289.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I suppose so.

290.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And that of which you can persuade either is clearly what you know?

291.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

292.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the only difference between one who argues as we are doing, and the orator who is addressing an assembly, is that the one seeks to persuade a number, and the other an individual, of the same things.

293.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I suppose so.

294.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, then, since the same person who can persuade a multitude can persuade individuals, try conclusions upon me, and prove to me that the just is not always expedient.

295.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: You take liberties, Socrates.

296.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I shall take the liberty of proving to you the opposite of that which you will not prove to me.

297.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Proceed.

298.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Answer my questions—that is all.

299.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Nay, I should like you to be the speaker.

300.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What, do you not wish to be persuaded?

301.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly I do.

302.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And can you be persuaded better than out of your own mouth?

303.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I think not.

304.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then you shall answer; and if you do not hear the words, that the just is the expedient, coming from your own lips, never believe another man again.

305.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I won't; but answer I will, for I do not see how I can come to any harm.

306.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: A true prophecy!
Let me begin then by enquiring of you whether you allow that the just is sometimes expedient and sometimes not?

307.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

308.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And sometimes honourable and sometimes not?

309.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What do you mean?

310.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I am asking if you ever knew any one who did what was dishonourable and yet just?

311.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Never.

312.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: All just things are honourable?

313.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

314.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And are honourable things sometimes good and sometimes not good, or are they always good?

315.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I rather think, Socrates, that some honourable things are evil.

316.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And are some dishonourable things good?

317.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

318.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You mean in such a case as the following: —In time of war, men have been wounded or have died in rescuing a companion or kinsman, when others who have neglected the duty of rescuing them have escaped in safety?

319.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

320.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And to rescue another under such circumstances is honourable, in respect of the attempt to save those whom we ought to save; and this is courage?

321.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

322.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But evil in respect of death and wounds?

323.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

324.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the courage which is shown in the rescue is one thing, and the death another?

325.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

326.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then the rescue of one's friends is honourable in one point of view, but evil in another?

327.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

328.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if honourable, then also good:  Will you consider now whether I may not be right, for you were acknowledging that the courage which is shown in the rescue is honourable?
Now is this courage good or evil?
Look at the matter thus:  which would you rather choose, good or evil?

329.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Good.

330.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the greatest goods you would be most ready to choose, and would least like to be deprived of them?

331.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

332.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What would you say of courage?
At what price would you be willing to be deprived of courage?

333.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I would rather die than be a coward.

334.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then you think that cowardice is the worst of evils?

335.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I do.

336.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: As bad as death, I suppose?

337.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

338.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And life and courage are the extreme opposites of death and cowardice?

339.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

340.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And they are what you would most desire to have, and their opposites you would least desire?

341.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

342.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Is this because you think life and courage the best, and death and cowardice the worst?

343.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

344.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And you would term the rescue of a friend in battle honourable, in as much as courage does a good work?

345.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I should.

346.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But evil because of the death which ensues?

347.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

348.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Might we not describe their different effects as follows: —You may call either of them evil in respect of the evil which is the result, and good in respect of the good which is the result of either of them?

349.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

350.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And they are honourable in so far as they are good, and dishonourable in so far as they are evil?

351.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

352.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then when you say that the rescue of a friend in battle is honourable and yet evil, that is equivalent to saying that the rescue is good and yet evil?

353.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I believe that you are right, Socrates.

354.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nothing honourable, regarded as honourable, is evil; nor anything base, regarded as base, good.

355.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Clearly not.

356.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Look at the matter yet once more in a further light:  he who acts honourably acts well?

357.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

358.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And he who acts well is happy?

359.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Of course.

360.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the happy are those who obtain good?

361.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

362.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And they obtain good by acting well and honourably?

363.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

364.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then acting well is a good?

365.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

366.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And happiness is a good?

367.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

368.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then the good and the honourable are again identified.

369.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Manifestly.

370.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then, if the argument holds, what we find to be honourable we shall also find to be good?

371.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

372.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is the good expedient or not?

373.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Expedient.

374.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Do you remember our admissions about the just?

375.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes; if I am not mistaken, we said that those who acted justly must also act honourably.

376.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the honourable is the good?

377.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

378.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the good is expedient?

379.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

380.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then, Alcibiades, the just is expedient?

381.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I should infer so.

382.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And all this I prove out of your own mouth, for I ask and you answer?

383.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I must acknowledge it to be true.

384.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And having acknowledged that the just is the same as the expedient, are you not (let me ask) prepared to ridicule any one who, pretending to understand the principles of justice and injustice, gets up to advise the noble Athenians or the ignoble Peparethians, that the just may be the evil?

385.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I solemnly declare, Socrates, that I do not know what I am saying.
Verily, I am in a strange state, for when you put questions to me I am of different minds in successive instants.

386.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And are you not aware of the nature of this perplexity, my friend?

387.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Indeed I am not.

388.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Do you suppose that if some one were to ask you whether you have two eyes or three, or two hands or four, or anything of that sort, you would then be of different minds in successive instants?

389.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I begin to distrust myself, but still I do not suppose that I should.

390.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You would feel no doubt; and for this reason—because you would know?

391.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I suppose so.

392.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the reason why you involuntarily contradict yourself is clearly that you are ignorant?

393.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Very likely.

394.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if you are perplexed in answering about just and unjust, honourable and dishonourable, good and evil, expedient and inexpedient, the reason is that you are ignorant of them, and therefore in perplexity.
Is not that clear?

395.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I agree.

396.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But is this always the case, and is a man necessarily perplexed about that of which he has no knowledge?

397.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly he is.

398.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do you know how to ascend into heaven?

399.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly not.

400.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And in this case, too, is your judgment perplexed?

401.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: No.

402.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Do you see the reason why, or shall I tell you?

403.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Tell me.

404.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The reason is, that you not only do not know, my friend, but you do not think that you know.

405.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: There again; what do you mean?

406.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Ask yourself; are you in any perplexity about things of which you are ignorant?
You know, for example, that you know nothing about the preparation of food.

407.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Very true.

408.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do you think and perplex yourself about the preparation of food:  or do you leave that to some one who understands the art?

409.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: The latter.

410.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Or if you were on a voyage, would you bewilder yourself by considering whether the rudder is to be drawn inwards or outwards, or do you leave that to the pilot, and do nothing?

411.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: It would be the concern of the pilot.

412.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then you are not perplexed about what you do not know, if you know that you do not know it?

413.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I imagine not.

414.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Do you not see, then, that mistakes in life and practice are likewise to be attributed to the ignorance which has conceit of knowledge?

415.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Once more, what do you mean?

416.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I suppose that we begin to act when we think that we know what we are doing?

417.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

418.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But when people think that they do not know, they entrust their business to others?

419.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

420.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And so there is a class of ignorant persons who do not make mistakes in life, because they trust others about things of which they are ignorant?

421.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

422.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Who, then, are the persons who make mistakes?
They cannot, of course, be those who know?

423.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly not.

424.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But if neither those who know, nor those who know that they do not know, make mistakes, there remain those only who do not know and think that they know.

425.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes, only those.

426.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then this is ignorance of the disgraceful sort which is mischievous?

427.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

428.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And most mischievous and most disgraceful when having to do with the greatest matters?

429.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: By far.

430.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And can there be any matters greater than the just, the honourable, the good, and the expedient?

431.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: There cannot be.

432.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And these, as you were saying, are what perplex you?

433.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

434.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But if you are perplexed, then, as the previous argument has shown, you are not only ignorant of the greatest matters, but being ignorant you fancy that you know them?

435.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I fear that you are right.

436.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now see what has happened to you, Alcibiades!

I hardly like to speak of your evil case, but as we are alone I will:  My good friend, you are wedded to ignorance of the most disgraceful kind, and of this you are convicted, not by me, but out of your own mouth and by your own argument; wherefore also you rush into politics before you are educated.
Neither is your case to be deemed singular.
For I might say the same of almost all our statesmen, with the exception, perhaps of your guardian, Pericles.

437.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes, Socrates; and Pericles is said not to have got his wisdom by the light of nature, but to have associated with several of the philosophers; with Pythocleides, for example, and with Anaxagoras, and now in advanced life with Damon, in the hope of gaining wisdom.

438.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Very good; but did you ever know a man wise in anything who was unable to impart his particular wisdom?
For example, he who taught you letters was not only wise, but he made you and any others whom he liked wise.

439.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

440.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And you, whom he taught, can do the same?

441.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

442.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And in like manner the harper and gymnastic-master?

443.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

444.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: When a person is enabled to impart knowledge to another, he thereby gives an excellent proof of his own understanding of any matter.

445.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I agree.

446.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, and did Pericles make any one wise; did he begin by making his sons wise?

447.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: But, Socrates, if the two sons of Pericles were simpletons, what has that to do with the matter?

448.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, but did he make your brother, Cleinias, wise?

449.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Cleinias is a madman; there is no use in talking of him.

450.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But if Cleinias is a madman and the two sons of Pericles were simpletons, what reason can be given why he neglects you, and lets you be as you are?

451.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I believe that I am to blame for not listening to him.

452.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But did you ever hear of any other Athenian or foreigner, bond or free, who was deemed to have grown wiser in the society of Pericles,—as I might cite Pythodorus, the son of Isolochus, and Callias, the son of Calliades, who have grown wiser in the society of Zeno, for which privilege they have each of them paid him the sum of a hundred minae (about 406 pounds sterling) to the increase of their wisdom and fame.

453.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I certainly never did hear of any one.

454.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, and in reference to your own case, do you mean to remain as you are, or will you take some pains about yourself?

455.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: With your aid, Socrates, I will.
And indeed, when I hear you speak, the truth of what you are saying strikes home to me, and I agree with you, for our statesmen, all but a few, do appear to be quite uneducated.

456.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What is the inference?

457.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Why, that if they were educated they would be trained athletes, and he who means to rival them ought to have knowledge and experience when he attacks them; but now, as they have become politicians without any special training, why should I have the trouble of learning and practising?
For I know well that by the light of nature I shall get the better of them.

458.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: My dear friend, what a sentiment!
And how unworthy of your noble form and your high estate!

459.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What do you mean, Socrates; why do you say so?

460.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I am grieved when I think of our mutual love.

461.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: At what?

462.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: At your fancying that the contest on which you are entering is with people here.

463.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Why, what others are there?

464.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Is that a question which a magnanimous soul should ask?

465.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Do you mean to say that the contest is not with these?

466.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And suppose that you were going to steer a ship into action, would you only aim at being the best pilot on board?
Would you not, while acknowledging that you must possess this degree of excellence, rather look to your antagonists, and not, as you are now doing, to your fellow combatants?

You ought to be so far above these latter, that they will not even dare to be your rivals; and, being regarded by you as inferiors, will do battle for you against the enemy; this is the kind of superiority which you must establish over them, if you mean to accomplish any noble action really worthy of yourself and of the state.

467.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That would certainly be my aim.

468.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Verily, then, you have good reason to be satisfied, if you are better than the soldiers; and you need not, when you are their superior and have your thoughts and actions fixed upon them, look away to the generals of the enemy.

469.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Of whom are you speaking, Socrates?

470.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Why, you surely know that our city goes to war now and then with the Lacedaemonians and with the great king?

471.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True enough.

472.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if you meant to be the ruler of this city, would you not be right in considering that the Lacedaemonian and Persian king were your true rivals?

473.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I believe that you are right.

474.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Oh no, my friend, I am quite wrong, and I think that you ought rather to turn your attention to Midias the quail-breeder and others like him, who manage our politics; in whom, as the women would remark, you may still see the slaves' cut of hair, cropping out in their minds as well as on their pates; and they come with their barbarous lingo to flatter us and not to rule us.

To these, I say, you should look, and then you need not trouble yourself about your own fitness to contend in such a noble arena:  there is no reason why you should either learn what has to be learned, or practise what has to be practised, and only when thoroughly prepared enter on a political career.

475.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: There, I think, Socrates, that you are right; I do not suppose, however, that the Spartan generals or the great king are really different from anybody else.

476.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But, my dear friend, do consider what you are saying.

477.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What am I to consider?

478.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In the first place, will you be more likely to take care of yourself, if you are in a wholesome fear and dread of them, or if you are not?

479.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Clearly, if I have such a fear of them.

480.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do you think that you will sustain any injury if you take care of yourself?

481.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: No, I shall be greatly benefited.

482.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And this is one very important respect in which that notion of yours is bad.

483.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

484.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In the next place, consider that what you say is probably false.

485.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: How so?

486.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let me ask you whether better natures are likely to be found in noble races or not in noble races?

487.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Clearly in noble races.

488.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Are not those who are well born and well bred most likely to be perfect in virtue?

489.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

490.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then let us compare our antecedents with those of the Lacedaemonian and Persian kings; are they inferior to us in descent?
Have we not heard that the former are sprung from Heracles, and the latter from Achaemenes, and that the race of Heracles and the race of Achaemenes go back to Perseus, son of Zeus?

491.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Why, so does mine go back to Eurysaces, and he to Zeus!

492.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And mine, noble Alcibiades, to Daedalus, and he to Hephaestus, son of Zeus.
But, for all that, we are far inferior to them.

For they are descended 'from Zeus,' through a line of kings—either kings of Argos and Lacedaemon, or kings of Persia, a country which the descendants of Achaemenes have always possessed, besides being at various times sovereigns of Asia, as they now are; whereas, we and our fathers were but private persons.

How ridiculous would you be thought if you were to make a display of your ancestors and of Salamis the island of Eurysaces, or of Aegina, the habitation of the still more ancient Aeacus, before Artaxerxes, son of Xerxes.
You should consider how inferior we are to them both in the derivation of our birth and in other particulars.
Did you never observe how great is the property of the Spartan kings?
And their wives are under the guardianship of the Ephori, who are public officers and watch over them, in order to preserve as far as possible the purity of the Heracleid blood.
Still greater is the difference among the Persians; for no one entertains a suspicion that the father of a prince of Persia can be any one but the king.
Such is the awe which invests the person of the queen, that any other guard is needless.

And when the heir of the kingdom is born, all the subjects of the king feast; and the day of his birth is for ever afterwards kept as a holiday and time of sacrifice by all Asia; whereas, when you and I were born, Alcibiades, as the comic poet says, the neighbours hardly knew of the important event.

After the birth of the royal child, he is tended, not by a good-for-nothing woman-nurse, but by the best of the royal eunuchs, who are charged with the care of him, and especially with the fashioning and right formation of his limbs, in order that he may be as shapely as possible; which being their calling, they are held in great honour.
And when the young prince is seven years old he is put upon a horse and taken to the riding-masters, and begins to go out hunting.

And at fourteen years of age he is handed over to the royal schoolmasters, as they are termed:  these are four chosen men, reputed to be the best among the Persians of a certain age; and one of them is the wisest, another the justest, a third the most temperate, and a fourth the most valiant.

The first instructs him in the magianism of Zoroaster, the son of Oromasus, which is the worship of the Gods, and teaches him also the duties of his royal office; the second, who is the justest, teaches him always to speak the truth; the third, or most temperate, forbids him to allow any pleasure to be lord over him, that he may be accustomed to be a freeman and king indeed,—lord of himself first, and not a slave; the most valiant trains him to be bold and fearless, telling him that if he fears he is to deem himself a slave; whereas Pericles gave you, Alcibiades, for a tutor Zopyrus the Thracian, a slave of his who was past all other work.
I might enlarge on the nurture and education of your rivals, but that would be tedious; and what I have said is a sufficient sample of what remains to be said.
I have only to remark, by way of contrast, that no one cares about your birth or nurture or education, or, I may say, about that of any other Athenian, unless he has a lover who looks after him.

And if you cast an eye on the wealth, the luxury, the garments with their flowing trains, the anointings with myrrh, the multitudes of attendants, and all the other bravery of the Persians, you will be ashamed when you discern your own inferiority; or if you look at the temperance and orderliness and ease and grace and magnanimity and courage and endurance and love of toil and desire of glory and ambition of the Lacedaemonians—in all these respects you will see that you are but a child in comparison of them.

Even in the matter of wealth, if you value yourself upon that, I must reveal to you how you stand; for if you form an estimate of the wealth of the Lacedaemonians, you will see that our possessions fall far short of theirs.

For no one here can compete with them either in the extent and fertility of their own and the Messenian territory, or in the number of their slaves, and especially of the Helots, or of their horses, or of the animals which feed on the Messenian pastures.

But I have said enough of this:  and as to gold and silver, there is more of them in Lacedaemon than in all the rest of Hellas, for during many generations gold has been always flowing in to them from the whole Hellenic world, and often from the barbarian also, and never going out, as in the fable of Aesop the fox said to the lion, 'The prints of the feet of those going in are distinct enough;' but who ever saw the trace of money going out of Lacedaemon?

And therefore you may safely infer that the inhabitants are the richest of the Hellenes in gold and silver, and that their kings are the richest of them, for they have a larger share of these things, and they have also a tribute paid to them which is very considerable.
Yet the Spartan wealth, though great in comparison of the wealth of the other Hellenes, is as nothing in comparison of that of the Persians and their kings.

Why, I have been informed by a credible person who went up to the king (at Susa), that he passed through a large tract of excellent land, extending for nearly a day's journey, which the people of the country called the queen's girdle, and another, which they called her veil; and several other fair and fertile districts, which were reserved for the adornment of the queen, and are named after her several habiliments.

Now, I cannot help thinking to myself, What if some one were to go to Amestris, the wife of Xerxes and mother of Artaxerxes, and say to her, There is a certain Dinomache, whose whole wardrobe is not worth fifty minae—and that will be more than the value—and she has a son who is possessed of a three-hundred acre patch at Erchiae, and he has a mind to go to war with your son—would she not wonder to what this Alcibiades trusts for success in the conflict?
'He must rely,' she would say to herself, 'upon his training and wisdom—these are the things which Hellenes value.'

And if she heard that this Alcibiades who is making the attempt is not as yet twenty years old, and is wholly uneducated, and when his lover tells him that he ought to get education and training first, and then go and fight the king, he refuses, and says that he is well enough as he is, would she not be amazed, and ask 'On what, then, does the youth rely?'

And if we replied:  He relies on his beauty, and stature, and birth, and mental endowments, she would think that we were mad, Alcibiades, when she compared the advantages which you possess with those of her own people.

And I believe that even Lampido, the daughter of Leotychides, the wife of Archidamus and mother of Agis, all of whom were kings, would have the same feeling; if, in your present uneducated state, you were to turn your thoughts against her son, she too would be equally astonished.
But how disgraceful, that we should not have as high a notion of what is required in us as our enemies' wives and mothers have of the qualities which are required in their assailants!
O my friend, be persuaded by me, and hear the Delphian inscription, 'Know thyself'—not the men whom you think, but these kings are our rivals, and we can only overcome them by pains and skill.
And if you fail in the required qualities, you will fail also in becoming renowned among Hellenes and Barbarians, which you seem to desire more than any other man ever desired anything.

493.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I entirely believe you; but what are the sort of pains which are required, Socrates,—can you tell me?

494.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Yes, I can; but we must take counsel together concerning the manner in which both of us may be most improved.
For what I am telling you of the necessity of education applies to myself as well as to you; and there is only one point in which I have an advantage over you.

495.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What is that?

496.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I have a guardian who is better and wiser than your guardian, Pericles.

497.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Who is he, Socrates?

498.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: God, Alcibiades, who up to this day has not allowed me to converse with you; and he inspires in me the faith that I am especially designed to bring you to honour.

499.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: You are jesting, Socrates.

500.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Perhaps, at any rate, I am right in saying that all men greatly need pains and care, and you and I above all men.

501.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: You are not far wrong about me.

502.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And certainly not about myself.

503.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: But what can we do?

504.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: There must be no hesitation or cowardice, my friend.

505.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That would not become us, Socrates.

506.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: No, indeed, and we ought to take counsel together:  for do we not wish to be as good as possible?

507.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: We do.

508.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In what sort of virtue?

509.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Plainly, in the virtue of good men.

510.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Who are good in what?

511.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Those, clearly, who are good in the management of affairs.

512.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What sort of affairs?
Equestrian affairs?

513.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly not.

514.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You mean that about them we should have recourse to horsemen?

515.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

516.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, naval affairs?

517.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: No.

518.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You mean that we should have recourse to sailors about them?

519.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

520.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then what affairs?
And who do them?

521.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: The affairs which occupy Athenian gentlemen.

522.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And when you speak of gentlemen, do you mean the wise or the unwise?

523.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: The wise.

524.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And a man is good in respect of that in which he is wise?

525.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

526.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And evil in respect of that in which he is unwise?

527.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

528.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The shoemaker, for example, is wise in respect of the making of shoes?

529.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

530.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then he is good in that?

531.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: He is.

532.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But in respect of the making of garments he is unwise?

533.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

534.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then in that he is bad?

535.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

536.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then upon this view of the matter the same man is good and also bad?

537.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

538.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But would you say that the good are the same as the bad?

539.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly not.

540.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then whom do you call the good?

541.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I mean by the good those who are able to rule in the city.

542.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Not, surely, over horses?

543.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly not.

544.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But over men?

545.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

546.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: When they are sick?

547.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: No.

548.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Or on a voyage?

549.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: No.

550.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Or reaping the harvest?

551.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: No.

552.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: When they are doing something or nothing?

553.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: When they are doing something, I should say.

554.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I wish that you would explain to me what this something is.

555.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: When they are having dealings with one another, and using one another's services, as we citizens do in our daily life.

556.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Those of whom you speak are ruling over men who are using the services of other men?

557.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

558.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Are they ruling over the signal-men who give the time to the rowers?

559.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: No; they are not.

560.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That would be the office of the pilot?

561.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

562.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But, perhaps you mean that they rule over flute-players, who lead the singers and use the services of the dancers?

563.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly not.

564.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That would be the business of the teacher of the chorus?

565.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

566.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then what is the meaning of being able to rule over men who use other men?

567.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I mean that they rule over men who have common rights of citizenship, and dealings with one another.

568.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what sort of an art is this?
Suppose that I ask you again, as I did just now, What art makes men know how to rule over their fellow-sailors,—how would you answer?

569.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: The art of the pilot.

570.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And, if I may recur to another old instance, what art enables them to rule over their fellow-singers?

571.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: The art of the teacher of the chorus, which you were just now mentioning.

572.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what do you call the art of fellow-citizens?

573.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I should say, good counsel, Socrates.

574.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is the art of the pilot evil counsel?

575.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: No.

576.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But good counsel?

577.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes, that is what I should say,—good counsel, of which the aim is the preservation of the voyagers.

578.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: True.
And what is the aim of that other good counsel of which you speak?

579.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: The aim is the better order and preservation of the city.

580.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what is that of which the absence or presence improves and preserves the order of the city?
Suppose you were to ask me, what is that of which the presence or absence improves or preserves the order of the body?
I should reply, the presence of health and the absence of disease.
You would say the same?

581.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

582.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if you were to ask me the same question about the eyes, I should reply in the same way, 'the presence of sight and the absence of blindness;' or about the ears, I should reply, that they were improved and were in better case, when deafness was absent, and hearing was present in them.

583.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

584.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what would you say of a state?
What is that by the presence or absence of which the state is improved and better managed and ordered?

585.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I should say, Socrates: —the presence of friendship and the absence of hatred and division.

586.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do you mean by friendship agreement or disagreement?

587.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Agreement.

588.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What art makes cities agree about numbers?

589.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Arithmetic.

590.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And private individuals?

591.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: The same.

592.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what art makes each individual agree with himself?

593.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: The same.

594.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what art makes each of us agree with himself about the comparative length of the span and of the cubit?
Does not the art of measure?

595.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

596.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Individuals are agreed with one another about this; and states, equally?

597.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

598.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the same holds of the balance?

599.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

600.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But what is the other agreement of which you speak, and about what?
what art can give that agreement?
And does that which gives it to the state give it also to the individual, so as to make him consistent with himself and with another?

601.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I should suppose so.

602.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But what is the nature of the agreement?—answer, and faint not.

603.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I mean to say that there should be such friendship and agreement as exists between an affectionate father and mother and their son, or between brothers, or between husband and wife.

604.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But can a man, Alcibiades, agree with a woman about the spinning of wool, which she understands and he does not?

605.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: No, truly.

606.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nor has he any need, for spinning is a female accomplishment.

607.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

608.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And would a woman agree with a man about the science of arms, which she has never learned?

609.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly not.

610.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I suppose that the use of arms would be regarded by you as a male accomplishment?

611.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: It would.

612.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then, upon your view, women and men have two sorts of knowledge?

613.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

614.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then in their knowledge there is no agreement of women and men?

615.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: There is not.

616.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nor can there be friendship, if friendship is agreement?

617.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Plainly not.

618.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then women are not loved by men when they do their own work?

619.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I suppose not.

620.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nor men by women when they do their own work?

621.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: No.

622.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nor are states well administered, when individuals do their own work?

623.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I should rather think, Socrates, that the reverse is the truth.
(Compare Republic.)

624.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What!
do you mean to say that states are well administered when friendship is absent, the presence of which, as we were saying, alone secures their good order?

625.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: But I should say that there is friendship among them, for this very reason, that the two parties respectively do their own work.

626.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That was not what you were saying before; and what do you mean now by affirming that friendship exists when there is no agreement?
How can there be agreement about matters which the one party knows, and of which the other is in ignorance?

627.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Impossible.

628.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And when individuals are doing their own work, are they doing what is just or unjust?

629.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What is just, certainly.

630.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And when individuals do what is just in the state, is there no friendship among them?

631.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I suppose that there must be, Socrates.

632.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then what do you mean by this friendship or agreement about which we must be wise and discreet in order that we may be good men?
I cannot make out where it exists or among whom; according to you, the same persons may sometimes have it, and sometimes not.

633.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: But, indeed, Socrates, I do not know what I am saying; and I have long been, unconsciously to myself, in a most disgraceful state.

634.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nevertheless, cheer up; at fifty, if you had discovered your deficiency, you would have been too old, and the time for taking care of yourself would have passed away, but yours is just the age at which the discovery should be made.

635.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: And what should he do, Socrates, who would make the discovery?

636.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Answer questions, Alcibiades; and that is a process which, by the grace of God, if I may put any faith in my oracle, will be very improving to both of us.

637.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: If I can be improved by answering, I will answer.

638.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And first of all, that we may not peradventure be deceived by appearances, fancying, perhaps, that we are taking care of ourselves when we are not, what is the meaning of a man taking care of himself?
and when does he take care?
Does he take care of himself when he takes care of what belongs to him?

639.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I should think so.

640.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: When does a man take care of his feet?
Does he not take care of them when he takes care of that which belongs to his feet?

641.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I do not understand.

642.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let me take the hand as an illustration; does not a ring belong to the finger, and to the finger only?

643.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

644.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the shoe in like manner to the foot?

645.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

646.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And when we take care of our shoes, do we not take care of our feet?

647.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I do not comprehend, Socrates.

648.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But you would admit, Alcibiades, that to take proper care of a thing is a correct expression?

649.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

650.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And taking proper care means improving?

651.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

652.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what is the art which improves our shoes?

653.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Shoemaking.

654.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then by shoemaking we take care of our shoes?

655.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

656.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do we by shoemaking take care of our feet, or by some other art which improves the feet?

657.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: By some other art.

658.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the same art improves the feet which improves the rest of the body?

659.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Very true.

660.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Which is gymnastic?

661.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

662.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then by gymnastic we take care of our feet, and by shoemaking of that which belongs to our feet?

663.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Very true.

664.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And by gymnastic we take care of our hands, and by the art of graving rings of that which belongs to our hands?

665.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

666.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And by gymnastic we take care of the body, and by the art of weaving and the other arts we take care of the things of the body?

667.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Clearly.

668.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then the art which takes care of each thing is different from that which takes care of the belongings of each thing?

669.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

670.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then in taking care of what belongs to you, you do not take care of yourself?

671.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly not.

672.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: For the art which takes care of our belongings appears not to be the same as that which takes care of ourselves?

673.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Clearly not.

674.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And now let me ask you what is the art with which we take care of ourselves?

675.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I cannot say.

676.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: At any rate, thus much has been admitted, that the art is not one which makes any of our possessions, but which makes ourselves better?

677.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

678.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But should we ever have known what art makes a shoe better, if we did not know a shoe?

679.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Impossible.

680.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nor should we know what art makes a ring better, if we did not know a ring?

681.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is true.

682.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And can we ever know what art makes a man better, if we do not know what we are ourselves?

683.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Impossible.

684.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is self-knowledge such an easy thing, and was he to be lightly esteemed who inscribed the text on the temple at Delphi?
Or is self-knowledge a difficult thing, which few are able to attain?

685.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: At times I fancy, Socrates, that anybody can know himself; at other times the task appears to be very difficult.

686.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But whether easy or difficult, Alcibiades, still there is no other way; knowing what we are, we shall know how to take care of ourselves, and if we are ignorant we shall not know.

687.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is true.

688.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Well, then, let us see in what way the self-existent can be discovered by us; that will give us a chance of discovering our own existence, which otherwise we can never know.

689.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: You say truly.

690.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Come, now, I beseech you, tell me with whom you are conversing?—with whom but with me?

691.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

692.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: As I am, with you?

693.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

694.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That is to say, I, Socrates, am talking?

695.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

696.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And Alcibiades is my hearer?

697.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

698.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And I in talking use words?

699.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

700.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And talking and using words have, I suppose, the same meaning?

701.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: To be sure.

702.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the user is not the same as the thing which he uses?

703.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What do you mean?

704.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I will explain; the shoemaker, for example, uses a square tool, and a circular tool, and other tools for cutting?

705.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

706.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But the tool is not the same as the cutter and user of the tool?

707.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Of course not.

708.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And in the same way the instrument of the harper is to be distinguished from the harper himself?

709.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: It is.

710.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Now the question which I asked was whether you conceive the user to be always different from that which he uses?

711.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I do.

712.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then what shall we say of the shoemaker?
Does he cut with his tools only or with his hands?

713.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: With his hands as well.

714.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: He uses his hands too?

715.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

716.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And does he use his eyes in cutting leather?

717.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: He does.

718.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And we admit that the user is not the same with the things which he uses?

719.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

720.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then the shoemaker and the harper are to be distinguished from the hands and feet which they use?

721.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Clearly.

722.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And does not a man use the whole body?

723.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

724.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And that which uses is different from that which is used?

725.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

726.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then a man is not the same as his own body?

727.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is the inference.

728.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What is he, then?

729.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I cannot say.

730.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nay, you can say that he is the user of the body.

731.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

732.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the user of the body is the soul?

733.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes, the soul.

734.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the soul rules?

735.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

736.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Let me make an assertion which will, I think, be universally admitted.

737.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What is it?

738.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That man is one of three things.

739.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What are they?

740.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Soul, body, or both together forming a whole.

741.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

742.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But did we not say that the actual ruling principle of the body is man?

743.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes, we did.

744.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And does the body rule over itself?

745.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly not.

746.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: It is subject, as we were saying?

747.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

748.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then that is not the principle which we are seeking?

749.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: It would seem not.

750.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But may we say that the union of the two rules over the body, and consequently that this is man?

751.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Very likely.

752.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The most unlikely of all things; for if one of the members is subject, the two united cannot possibly rule.

753.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

754.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But since neither the body, nor the union of the two, is man, either man has no real existence, or the soul is man?

755.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Just so.

756.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Is anything more required to prove that the soul is man?

757.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly not; the proof is, I think, quite sufficient.

758.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if the proof, although not perfect, be sufficient, we shall be satisfied;—more precise proof will be supplied when we have discovered that which we were led to omit, from a fear that the enquiry would be too much protracted.

759.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What was that?

760.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What I meant, when I said that absolute existence must be first considered; but now, instead of absolute existence, we have been considering the nature of individual existence, and this may, perhaps, be sufficient; for surely there is nothing which may be called more properly ourselves than the soul?

761.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: There is nothing.

762.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then we may truly conceive that you and I are conversing with one another, soul to soul?

763.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Very true.

764.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And that is just what I was saying before—that I, Socrates, am not arguing or talking with the face of Alcibiades, but with the real Alcibiades; or in other words, with his soul.

765.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

766.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then he who bids a man know himself, would have him know his soul?

767.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That appears to be true.

768.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: He whose knowledge only extends to the body, knows the things of a man, and not the man himself?

769.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is true.

770.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then neither the physician regarded as a physician, nor the trainer regarded as a trainer, knows himself?

771.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: He does not.

772.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The husbandmen and the other craftsmen are very far from knowing themselves, for they would seem not even to know their own belongings?
When regarded in relation to the arts which they practise they are even further removed from self-knowledge, for they only know the belongings of the body, which minister to the body.

773.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is true.

774.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then if temperance is the knowledge of self, in respect of his art none of them is temperate?

775.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I agree.

776.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And this is the reason why their arts are accounted vulgar, and are not such as a good man would practise?

777.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Quite true.

778.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Again, he who cherishes his body cherishes not himself, but what belongs to him?

779.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is true.

780.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But he who cherishes his money, cherishes neither himself nor his belongings, but is in a stage yet further removed from himself?

781.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I agree.

782.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then the money-maker has really ceased to be occupied with his own concerns?

783.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

784.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if any one has fallen in love with the person of Alcibiades, he loves not Alcibiades, but the belongings of Alcibiades?

785.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

786.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But he who loves your soul is the true lover?

787.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is the necessary inference.

788.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The lover of the body goes away when the flower of youth fades?

789.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

790.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But he who loves the soul goes not away, as long as the soul follows after virtue?

791.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

792.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And I am the lover who goes not away, but remains with you, when you are no longer young and the rest are gone?

793.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes, Socrates; and therein you do well, and I hope that you will remain.

794.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then you must try to look your best.

795.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I will.

796.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The fact is, that there is only one lover of Alcibiades the son of Cleinias; there neither is nor ever has been seemingly any other; and he is his darling,—Socrates, the son of Sophroniscus and Phaenarete.

797.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

798.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And did you not say, that if I had not spoken first, you were on the point of coming to me, and enquiring why I only remained?

799.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is true.

800.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The reason was that I loved you for your own sake, whereas other men love what belongs to you; and your beauty, which is not you, is fading away, just as your true self is beginning to bloom.
And I will never desert you, if you are not spoiled and deformed by the Athenian people; for the danger which I most fear is that you will become a lover of the people and will be spoiled by them.
Many a noble Athenian has been ruined in this way.
For the demus of the great-hearted Erechteus is of a fair countenance, but you should see him naked; wherefore observe the caution which I give you.

801.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What caution?

802.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Practise yourself, sweet friend, in learning what you ought to know, before you enter on politics; and then you will have an antidote which will keep you out of harm's way.

803.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Good advice, Socrates, but I wish that you would explain to me in what way I am to take care of myself.

804.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Have we not made an advance?

for we are at any rate tolerably well agreed as to what we are, and there is no longer any danger, as we once feared, that we might be taking care not of ourselves, but of something which is not ourselves.

805.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is true.

806.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the next step will be to take care of the soul, and look to that?

807.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

808.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Leaving the care of our bodies and of our properties to others?

809.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Very good.

810.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But how can we have a perfect knowledge of the things of the soul?—For if we know them, then I suppose we shall know ourselves.
Can we really be ignorant of the excellent meaning of the Delphian inscription, of which we were just now speaking?

811.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What have you in your thoughts, Socrates?

812.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I will tell you what I suspect to be the meaning and lesson of that inscription.
Let me take an illustration from sight, which I imagine to be the only one suitable to my purpose.

813.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What do you mean?

814.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Consider; if some one were to say to the eye, 'See thyself,' as you might say to a man, 'Know thyself,' what is the nature and meaning of this precept?
Would not his meaning be: —That the eye should look at that in which it would see itself?

815.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Clearly.

816.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what are the objects in looking at which we see ourselves?

817.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Clearly, Socrates, in looking at mirrors and the like.

818.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Very true; and is there not something of the nature of a mirror in our own eyes?

819.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

820.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Did you ever observe that the face of the person looking into the eye of another is reflected as in a mirror; and in the visual organ which is over against him, and which is called the pupil, there is a sort of image of the person looking?

821.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is quite true.

822.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then the eye, looking at another eye, and at that in the eye which is most perfect, and which is the instrument of vision, will there see itself?

823.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is evident.

824.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But looking at anything else either in man or in the world, and not to what resembles this, it will not see itself?

825.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Very true.

826.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then if the eye is to see itself, it must look at the eye, and at that part of the eye where sight which is the virtue of the eye resides?

827.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

828.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if the soul, my dear Alcibiades, is ever to know herself, must she not look at the soul; and especially at that part of the soul in which her virtue resides, and to any other which is like this?

829.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I agree, Socrates.

830.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do we know of any part of our souls more divine than that which has to do with wisdom and knowledge?

831.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: There is none.

832.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then this is that part of the soul which resembles the divine; and he who looks at this and at the whole class of things divine, will be most likely to know himself?

833.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Clearly.

834.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And self-knowledge we agree to be wisdom?

835.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

836.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But if we have no self-knowledge and no wisdom, can we ever know our own good and evil?

837.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: How can we, Socrates?

838.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You mean, that if you did not know Alcibiades, there would be no possibility of your knowing that what belonged to Alcibiades was really his?

839.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: It would be quite impossible.

840.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nor should we know that we were the persons to whom anything belonged, if we did not know ourselves?

841.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: How could we?

842.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if we did not know our own belongings, neither should we know the belongings of our belongings?

843.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Clearly not.

844.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then we were not altogether right in acknowledging just now that a man may know what belongs to him and yet not know himself; nay, rather he cannot even know the belongings of his belongings; for the discernment of the things of self, and of the things which belong to the things of self, appear all to be the business of the same man, and of the same art.

845.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: So much may be supposed.

846.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And he who knows not the things which belong to himself, will in like manner be ignorant of the things which belong to others?

847.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Very true.

848.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if he knows not the affairs of others, he will not know the affairs of states?

849.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly not.

850.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then such a man can never be a statesman?

851.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: He cannot.

852.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Nor an economist?

853.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: He cannot.

854.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: He will not know what he is doing?

855.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: He will not.

856.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And will not he who is ignorant fall into error?

857.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Assuredly.

858.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if he falls into error will he not fail both in his public and private capacity?

859.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes, indeed.

860.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And failing, will he not be miserable?

861.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Very.

862.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what will become of those for whom he is acting?

863.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: They will be miserable also.

864.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then he who is not wise and good cannot be happy?

865.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: He cannot.

866.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: The bad, then, are miserable?

867.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes, very.

868.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if so, not he who has riches, but he who has wisdom, is delivered from his misery?

869.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Clearly.

870.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Cities, then, if they are to be happy, do not want walls, or triremes, or docks, or numbers, or size, Alcibiades, without virtue?
(Compare Arist.
Pol.)

871.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Indeed they do not.

872.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And you must give the citizens virtue, if you mean to administer their affairs rightly or nobly?

873.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

874.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But can a man give that which he has not?

875.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Impossible.

876.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then you or any one who means to govern and superintend, not only himself and the things of himself, but the state and the things of the state, must in the first place acquire virtue.

877.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is true.

878.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You have not therefore to obtain power or authority, in order to enable you to do what you wish for yourself and the state, but justice and wisdom.

879.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Clearly.

880.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You and the state, if you act wisely and justly, will act according to the will of God?

881.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

882.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: As I was saying before, you will look only at what is bright and divine, and act with a view to them?

883.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

884.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In that mirror you will see and know yourselves and your own good?

885.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

886.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And so you will act rightly and well?

887.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

888.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In which case, I will be security for your happiness.

889.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I accept the security.

890.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But if you act unrighteously, your eye will turn to the dark and godless, and being in darkness and ignorance of yourselves, you will probably do deeds of darkness.

891.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Very possibly.

892.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: For if a man, my dear Alcibiades, has the power to do what he likes, but has no understanding, what is likely to be the result, either to him as an individual or to the state—for example, if he be sick and is able to do what he likes, not having the mind of a physician—having moreover tyrannical power, and no one daring to reprove him, what will happen to him?
Will he not be likely to have his constitution ruined?

893.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is true.

894.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Or again, in a ship, if a man having the power to do what he likes, has no intelligence or skill in navigation, do you see what will happen to him and to his fellow-sailors?

895.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes; I see that they will all perish.

896.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And in like manner, in a state, and where there is any power and authority which is wanting in virtue, will not misfortune, in like manner, ensue?

897.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

898.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Not tyrannical power, then, my good Alcibiades, should be the aim either of individuals or states, if they would be happy, but virtue.

899.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is true.

900.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And before they have virtue, to be commanded by a superior is better for men as well as for children?
(Compare Arist.
Pol.)

901.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: That is evident.

902.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And that which is better is also nobler?

903.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

904.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what is nobler is more becoming?

905.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly.

906.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then to the bad man slavery is more becoming, because better?

907.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: True.

908.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then vice is only suited to a slave?

909.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

910.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And virtue to a freeman?

911.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes.

912.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And, O my friend, is not the condition of a slave to be avoided?

913.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Certainly, Socrates.

914.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And are you now conscious of your own state?
And do you know whether you are a freeman or not?

915.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I think that I am very conscious indeed of my own state.

916.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And do you know how to escape out of a state which I do not even like to name to my beauty?

917.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Yes, I do.

918.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: How?

919.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: By your help, Socrates.

920.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: That is not well said, Alcibiades.

921.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: What ought I to have said?

922.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: By the help of God.

923.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: I agree; and I further say, that our relations are likely to be reversed.
From this day forward, I must and will follow you as you have followed me; I will be the disciple, and you shall be my master.

924.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: O that is rare!
My love breeds another love:  and so like the stork I shall be cherished by the bird whom I have hatched.

925.speaker: ALCIBIADES
sentences: Strange, but true; and henceforward I shall begin to think about justice.

926.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And I hope that you will persist; although I have fears, not because I doubt you; but I see the power of the state, which may be too much for both of us.
